an8.7:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
an8.7:4.2: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
an8.7:4.3: “Mendicants, it’s good for a mendicant to review their own failings from time to time.
an8.7:4.4: It’s good for a mendicant to review the failings of others from time to time.
an8.7:4.5: It’s good for a mendicant to review their own successes from time to time.
an8.7:4.6: It’s good for a mendicant to review the successes of others from time to time.
an8.7:4.7: Overcome and overwhelmed by eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an8.7:5.9: bad friendship, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an8.7:5.10: Overcome and overwhelmed by these eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.
an8.7:6.1: It’s good for a mendicant, whenever they encounter it, to overcome gain … loss …
an8.7:7.1: What advantage does a mendicant gain by overcoming these eight things?
an8.7:8.1: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without overcoming these eight things do not arise when they have overcome them.
an8.7:8.9: This is the advantage that a mendicant gains by overcoming these eight things.
an8.7:9.1: So, mendicants, you should train like this:
an8.7:9.2: ‘Whenever we encounter it, we will overcome gain … loss …
